description.plain:
Agust D is one of the stage names of Min Yoongi, a South Korean rapper, composer, songwriter and producer. He is also known as SUGA, the lead rapper of BTS.

“Agust D” is composed of two anagrams: ‘AGUS’ is his BTS stage name reversed, and ’T D' comes from D-Town, his former underground hip-hop group from Daegu.

In an interview with TIME Magazine, Yoongi establishes the differences and similarities between his positions as ‘SUGA of BTS’ and ‘Agust D’:

The difference is that there is a lot more that I can openly express and that I can show a more raw side to myself [with Agust D]. What’s similar is that both sing of dreams and hope.

On August 2016, he released his first solo mixtape, Agust D on SoundCloud. In 2018 the mixtape was rereleased for digital purchase and streaming, but without two first tracks which contained commercial samples (they were added in 2023 after the sample clearance).

Four years after its initial release, on May 2020, the second mixtape, D-2, was released. It achieved, among others, #1 on iTunes Albums Charts in 106 countries.

His third album, D-DAY, remarking his solo studio album debut, released on April 2023 with the accompanying World Tour.

body.plain:
Agust D is one of the stage names of Min Yoongi, a South Korean rapper, composer, songwriter and producer. He is also known as SUGA, the lead rapper of BTS.

“Agust D” is composed of two anagrams: ‘AGUS’ is his BTS stage name reversed, and ’T D' comes from D-Town, his former underground hip-hop group from Daegu.

In an interview with TIME Magazine, Yoongi establishes the differences and similarities between his positions as ‘SUGA of BTS’ and ‘Agust D’:

The difference is that there is a lot more that I can openly express and that I can show a more raw side to myself [with Agust D]. What’s similar is that both sing of dreams and hope.

On August 2016, he released his first solo mixtape, Agust D on SoundCloud. In 2018 the mixtape was rereleased for digital purchase and streaming, but without two first tracks which contained commercial samples (they were added in 2023 after the sample clearance).

Four years after its initial release, on May 2020, the second mixtape, D-2, was released. It achieved, among others, #1 on iTunes Albums Charts in 106 countries.

His third album, D-DAY, remarking his solo studio album debut, released on April 2023 with the accompanying World Tour.

songs.title: Agust D

description.plain:
“Agust D” is the title track for Agust D’s self titled mixtape. The track features intense rap over an old-school-hip-hop-influenced beat, and it samples James Brown’s 1966 hit “It’s a Man’s Man’s Man’s World”.

The lyrics are made up of eye-opening remarks concerning the constraints of being a K-pop star with lines like:

This K-pop category ain’t enough size for me.

The lyrics also offer an unexpected take on why the industry should be glad Yoongi’s in the Korean music industry. The perceived weakness that most K-pop idols can’t be legitimate MCs becomes a strength. The rap scene is actually lucky Agust D is just an alter ego or it’d be game over. Yoongi also drops bold catchphrases like “Ya’ll get turned on by ma tongue technology” that one typically wouldn’t find in a K-pop song.

When asked in an interview with Marie Claire Yoongi describes the direction he wanted to focus on with his music:

I wanted to express myself transparently with the purpose of doing everything I wanted to do.”

songs.embed_content: Read “Agust D” by Agust D on Genius

The lyrics are made up of eye-opening remarks concerning the constraints of being a K-pop star with lines like:

This K-pop category ain’t enough size for me.

The lyrics also offer an unexpected take on why the industry should be glad Yoongi’s in the Korean music industry. The perceived weakness that most K-pop idols can’t be legitimate MCs becomes a strength. The rap scene is actually lucky Agust D is just an alter ego or it’d be game over. Yoongi also drops bold catchphrases like “Ya’ll get turned on by ma tongue technology” that one typically wouldn’t find in a K-pop song.

When asked in an interview with Marie Claire Yoongi describes the direction he wanted to focus on with his music:

I wanted to express myself transparently with the purpose of doing everything I wanted to do.”

songs.title: 마지막 (The Last)

description.plain:
“The Last” Is the seventh song of Agust D (aka Daegu Town Suga)’s self-titled mixtape. With lyrics like “Depression, OCD; They keep coming back again from time to time”, it’s one of the most personal, emotional songs of the EP.

In South Korea, there is stigma around mental illness, meaning many people refrain from seeking treatment and help, and the topic is rarely ever discussed. This song is therefore revolutionary in itself as Agust D, a well known artist, opens up about his struggles with depression and anxiety, which in turn may help in changing the stigmatized view of mental illness in South Korea.

songs.embed_content: Read “마지막 (The Last)” by Agust D on Genius

songs.title: 대취타 (Daechwita)

description.plain:
The song acts as the lead single off of the mixtape, D-2. The title of the song references traditional Korean military music. The arrangement is usually performed with wind and percussion instruments. In true military style, it is performed while marching and wearing proper military attire.

Agust D shared that the main purpose of this song is to be ‘a sort of trap’ for his haters.

The music video is in-line with this theme by portraying a sageuk storyline and was filmed at MBC DaeJanggeum Park. Many South Korean dramas have been shot at the location as well.

songs.embed_content: Read “대취타 (Daechwita)” by Agust D on Genius

body.plain:
The song acts as the lead single off of the mixtape, D-2. The title of the song references traditional Korean military music. The arrangement is usually performed with wind and percussion instruments. In true military style, it is performed while marching and wearing proper military attire.

Agust D shared that the main purpose of this song is to be ‘a sort of trap’ for his haters.

The music video is in-line with this theme by portraying a sageuk storyline and was filmed at MBC DaeJanggeum Park. Many South Korean dramas have been shot at the location as well.
